Electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is essential in fuel cells and metal-air batteries for converting and storing energy. Nevertheless, these devices suffer from ORR's slow kinetics at cathode surfaces, necessitating effective electrocatalysts. To meet the practical application of these devices, various ORR electrocatalysts, including transition metal oxides (TMOs), sulfides (TMSs), phosphides (TMPs), and single-atom catalysts (SACs), have been developed, each with its issues related to limited activity, selectivity, and durability. Although TMOs possessed promise towards ORR, their limited conductivity and poor selectivity motivated the researcher to perform their sulfurization and phosphorization, resulting in TMSs, TMPs, and SACs, which displayed good ORR. However, at a practical level, these catalysts still exhibited poor selectivity and durability, introducing a novel class of electrocatalysts, ‘dual-atom catalysts (DACs)’. DACs have many advantages, including maximum atomic utilization in catalysis and a well-established activity descriptor, over other electrocatalysts. However, an assessment of DAC's evolution, their promise towards ORR, and the learned concepts to design efficient ORR catalysts is required. The purpose of this review is to provide a road map of the transition of electrocatalysts from TMOs to DACs with recent advancements in chemistry, structural-functional relationships, advantages, and disadvantages. In addition, the challenges, and relative prospects of various critical parameters of ORR electrocatalysts are also covered systematically. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalysts Oxygen reduction reaction Fuel cells Transition metal oxides Single-atom And dual-atom catalysts Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction 1.1 Logical inspirations As a result of the continually increasing global population and a simultaneously increasing demand for energy, the global environment is at a significant threat as current energy sources are primarily of petrochemical origin. This is a major factor contributing to the global warming crisis while also causing adverse environmental effects. Therefore, it is crucial to address these concerns by developing renewable energy technology that is environmentally benign. Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and metal-air batteries (MABs) are two renewable energy technologies that have recently gained attention for their impressive reliability, minimal pollutant emissions, and high energy densities. For both PEMFCs and MABs, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode is the backbone of the electrochemical energy conversion process, with their performance heavily influenced by the efficiency of the reaction. The cathodic ORR is, however, plagued with sluggish kinetics, which has served as a major bottleneck in the further development of devices such as PEMFCs and MABs. Therefore, to resolve the kinetics issue, suitable electrocatalysts for ORR must be identified and/or developed to boost the overall reaction kinetics. 1.2 Role of electrocatalysts In electrochemical devices such as MABs and PEMFCs, the ORR process occurs at the cathode followed by the general steps; (i) diffusion and adsorption of O2 molecules at the electrocatalyst surface, (ii) transportation of electrons from the anode to the adsorbed O2 molecules, (iii) weakening and splitting of O=O bonds, and (iv) removal of produced OH− ions into solution [1]. Usually, ORR can follow two main pathways, (i) the two-electron reaction pathway (Eq. 1 and Eq. 2) or (ii) the four-electron reaction pathway (Eq. 3 and Eq. 4) [2] as shown in Fig. 1 . (1) O 2 + 2 ( H + + e − ) → H 2 O 2 E o = 0.70 V (2) O 2 + 2 ( H + + e − ) → * O O H + ( H + + e − ) → H 2 O 2 (3) O 2 + 4 ( H + + e − ) → H 2 O E o = 1.23 V (4) O 2 + 4 ( H + + e − ) → * O O H + 3 ( H + + e − ) → * O + 2 ( H + + e − ) → * O H + ( H + + e − ) → 2 H 2 O The 2 e − reaction pathway severely reduces energy conversion efficiency and device durability, while the direct 4 e − reaction pathway is generally considered the best for electrochemical applications due to the absence of hydrogen peroxide production [2,3]. The main ORR bottleneck is the slow kinetics of the entire reaction, which limits the total output power density of fuel cells (FCs) and MABs. As shown in Eqs. 1–4 [1], the slow reaction kinetics are mainly caused by the different adsorption/desorption and reaction pathways, which comprise a variety of intermediates containing oxygen, including OOH, O, and OH (*, active site). The extraordinarily high bond energy of 498 kJ/mol makes electrochemical bond breakage of the OO bond exceedingly challenging [1]. Strong and stable electrocatalysts at the cathode are necessary to overcome these obstacles and improve the ORR reaction kinetics. The bond cleavage process is facilitated by the use of electrocatalysts, which lower the energy barrier [4,5]. 1.3 Evolution from transition metal oxides to dual atom catalysts Commercially, Pt-based electrocatalysts are now the most used for sustainable energy storage and conversion. Because of its high catalytic activity and exceptional stability in acidic electrolytes compared to other noble metals [6–23]. Pt has been extensively researched and acknowledged as the ideal element for these electrochemical applications [24]. Nevertheless, Pt's limited availability and high cost significantly restrict its application on a big scale. To this end, researchers have directed their efforts to develop non-Pt-based electrocatalysts that are cost-efficient, stable, and highly active to replace Pt-based electrodes. These electrocatalysts include transition metal oxides (TMOs), transition metal sulfides (TMSs), transition metal phosphides (TMPs), single-atom catalysts (SACs), and dual atom catalysts (DACs) (Fig. 2 ). In the development of several crucial sustainable technologies, TMOs play a significant role. Because of their unusual electrical structure, which includes unfilled valence layer 3d-orbitals and losable unpaired single electrons, they are particularly susceptible to ORR and can improve electrochemical processes in general [25]. TMOs are generally low-cost due to the vast abundance of most of the transition metals, with additional advantages being realized in environmental friendliness, excellent stability, high theoretical capacity, and intrinsic activity. However, their main drawbacks are poor electrical conductivity, small specific surface area, and much lower actual electrochemical activities and capacities as compared to the theoretical values [25]. TMSs have attracted a similar increased research interest, owing to their rich composition, good electron transport capabilities, and unique lattice structure [26]. Additionally, they have a more suitable electronic band gap and band position when compared to TMOs. For TMPs, research efforts have mainly focused on their development as electrocatalysts owing to their long stability, and excellent catalytic properties ORR in alkaline solutions [27,28]. Additionally, TMPs exhibit higher ORR activity and electrical conductivity when compared to their corresponding TMOs [28]. However, their electrical conductivity is still not satisfactory for electrochemical applications [29]. In this context, SACs are a unique class of electrocatalysts that have garnered significant research attention in recent years owing to their maximum atom utilization efficiency, excellent catalytic performance, and tunable electronic structures [2,30]. Additionally, SACs display outstanding catalytic activity for ORR and are thus of significant interest for fuel cell and MAB applications [2,31,32]. However, the ORR linear scaling relationship still limits their catalytic activity. To address this issue, a lot of strategies including the incorporation of booster atomic sites, ligands, and dopants, confinement modification, construction of interfacial sites, and electrolyte as well as solvent engineering, have been experimented. However, their ideal catalytic performance towards ORR is still yet to come [2]. Compared to SACs, DACs possess two atomic sites (M1 and M2) in their first and second coordination shells (Fig. 3a ) [33]. These DACs provide electronic effects, where M1 acts as the active site and M2 as the electronic regulator. They also exhibit an adsorption effect, where additional sites modify the adsorption structures to surpass the limit imposed by the scaling relationship. Furthermore, DACs demonstrate synergistic effects, where M1 and M2 sites independently catalyze different core steps during the ORR process. These combined effects allow DACs to overcome the linear scaling relationship of ORR and enhance the catalytic performance in ORR. Furthermore, the manipulation of the electrical configuration and coordination environment of DACs can control their combined ability to adsorb reactants and reaction intermediates, hence enhancing the kinetics of the ORR process [34,35]. While the DFT computation provided insight at the atomic level, there is a significant disparity between the actual situation and the operational conditions. The use of characterization equipment is required to ensure the existence of single-atom species, much as theoretical simulation is vital to uncovering the mechanism involved in electrocatalytic reactions with DACs. Researchers have conducted several theoretical simulations to comprehend catalytic mechanisms and the structure-activity relationship. The goal is to apply this acquired information to the design of ideal DACs, not only for ORR but also for other electrocatalytic processes (Fig. 3(b-c)) [36–38]. The association between experimental and theoretical investigations is critical for comprehending tricky dual-atomic sites, developing them systematically, and exploring their future practical applications. 1.4 Scope of this work As evidenced in the previous section, the field of electrocatalytic materials has been widely studied. Several reviews and perspectives have been published on this topic [2,30,34,35,39–57]. However, they typically mainly focus on one electrocatalytic material or tend to separate transition metal electrocatalysts from atomically dispersed catalysts as opposed to discussing both in a single review. This review seeks to offer a comprehensive analysis of the developments in electrocatalytic materials for ORR by systematically discussing the major non-Pt-based electrocatalytic materials that have been extensively studied in recent years, namely TMOs, TMSs, TMPs, SACs, and DACs. We believe this will enable the readership to obtain a precise and comprehensive view of the major developments in electrocatalytic ORR materials. We discuss not only the chemistry of these materials and their utilization as ORR electrocatalysts but also provide prospects for the improvement of the electrocatalytic performance of these electrocatalysts for their potential applications in different technologies, such as fuel cells and MABs. 2 Advances in transition metal-based electrocatalysts When developing ORR electroactive materials, it is crucial to be familiar with the linear scaling relationships. Depending on the metal used for electrocatalysis, the three intermediates of the associative ORR mechanism, *OOH, *O, and *OH, can vary greatly. Lastly, there is a strong connection between the ORR process's overall overpotential and the binding energy of the intermediates across the electrocatalyst surface. One of the goals of optimizing the ORR process is to produce binding energies that allow for sufficient chemisorption of the intermediates without binding them too strongly or too weakly to the substrate [58]. In this context, among various developed electrocatalysts, TMOs, TMSs, TMPs, and atomically dispersed catalysts have been utilized as promising electrocatalysts. This section discusses implemented approaches to boost the electrocatalytic ORR performances for TMOs, TMSs, TMPs, and atomically dispersed catalysts. 2.1 Transition metal oxides Oxygen atoms typically form bonds with transition metals (TMs) in TMOs; the type of these bonds is dictated by the metal's oxidation state; ionic bonding is associated with low oxidation states; and covalent bonding is associated with high oxidation states [59]. The electronic structure of a given TMO is largely influenced by their d-electrons. Most transition metals have partially filled d-orbitals, with three fundamental features namely: (i) the orbital, (ii) charge, and (iii) spin [60]. The first-order features of orbital, charge, and spin are largely dictated by the lattice of TMOs and can combine to create other features in the TMOs lattice, such as electronic band structure, local exchange interactions, and magnetic ordering. The band structure of TMOs can be indicated by coupling between electrons and crystal orbitals, owing to the nature of strongly correlated electron systems. In a general sense, the d-electrons in most TMOs are localized and display insulating behavior owing to strong electron correlation. This differs from conventional metal bands in which the d-electron state is narrow and consecutive across the Fermi level [60]. Although these features of TMOs make them good materials to catalyze ORR efficiently, their ideal performance is yet to come. For optimal intermediate binding during ORR, one approach is to manipulate the TM's surface, geometry, and electrical configuration. Among various TM-based oxides, Co, Mn, and Fe oxide-based electrocatalysts are the most widely studied [61–72]. Cobalt oxides have gotten a lot of attention as ORR nano-electrocatalysts because they are cheap, have a high theoretical capacity (890 mAh/g), and have a large surface area while keeping their chemical states stable [52]. Co3O4 with spinel structure characterized by Co2+ and Co3+ occupying tetrahedral and octahedral voids respectively are particularly advantageous owing to the presence of the Co2+/Co3+ redox couple which facilitates the transfer of electron states [52]. However, poor conductivity and stability of these TMOs are the big issues for their implementation as ORR electrocatalysts. In this context, improving TMOs' ORR performance can be as simple as fabricating nanostructures based on TMOs and then attaching them to a conductive support. To back up this approach, graphene is the go-to conductive support material due to its remarkable electrical, mechanical, and thermal capabilities. Also, materials made of graphene have a lot of surface area, are very stable, and can withstand chemicals far better than others. Though applicable to various TMO-based electrocatalysts, this approach works particularly well with cobalt oxides with a low specific surface area, a large particle size, and instability in acidic environments [52]. For example, to facilitate the O2 reduction process in Zn-air batteries, Xu et al. [73] contained the Co-oxide NPs in N-doped graphene (referred to as CoO/NG) using hydrothermal and high-temperature calcination (Fig. 4a ). The results show that the CoO/NG's large specific surface area and large number of mesoporous structures speed up several steps in the reaction, such as the activation, transfer, and adsorption of reactants. Using N-doped graphene as the carbon base also spreads the CoO nanoparticles out more evenly, which opens more active sites in the CoO/NG electrocatalyst (Fig. 4(b–d)). Furthermore, N-doping changes the electrical structure and raises the number of active sites, which makes it easier for oxygen and intermediates to bind. These characteristics help explain the exceptional ORR activity that CoO/NG exhibits, as shown in Fig. 4f with E 1/ 2 = 0.830 V and Fig. 4e with a Tafel slope of 46.2 mV/dec. With an electron transfer number of 4.1, the CoO/NG ORR demonstrated that the ORR reaction path was the 4e-reaction process of choice. However, Mn-based TMOs like perovskite (AMnO3) and spinel (AMn2O4) are good at ORR because they are very stable, cheap, easy to find, and can be in a lot of different oxidation states. However, their high electrical resistance is still a major problem that prevents them from being used as electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reactions. Adding flaws or empty spaces to Mn oxides has made them more ORR-active by changing the Mn4+ state to Mn3+, which is a more ORR-active site with better electrical conductivity [52]. A vacancy is a space in the crystal structure that results from the absence of an atom [57]. Rearranging local electron densities and increasing densities in states close to the Fermi level are two common effects of the vacancy site [57]. To be more precise, vacancies optimize the electronic structure and atomic coordination environment of TMOs, which in turn increases their intrinsic electrical conductivity. This causes a strain on the surface of the catalyst, which increases the energy required for ORR intermediates to adsorb to the surface [37]. As an illustration, Zhang et al. [74] produced Mn-deficient Mn3O4 using a solvothermal method and thermal calcination. By adding Mn vacancies to Mn3O4, the electronic structure, conductivity, and electronic delocalization were all found to be better. Enhanced oxygen activation and *OH desorption is both made possible by the increased exposure of surfaces to Mn3+ active sites, which in turn decreases the fluctuation in the ORR rate-limiting step's Gibbs free energy. Consequently, compared to normal Mn3O4, which had an onset potential of 0.77 V, a half-wave potential of 0.65 V, and a limiting current density of 2.6 mA/cm2, manganese-deficient Mn3O4 had more favorable electrical characteristics. This proves that increasing Mn3O4's ORR activity via metal-vacancy manipulation was a successful strategy. On the other hand, interface engineering is another viable strategy in the design of TMOs with enhanced ORR catalytic performance. As a result of the formation of interface in hetero compounds, defects such as interfacial dislocations and structural discontinuities can occur [76]. Boundary flaws on the contact can enhance electronic coupling between different coupling zones. Moreover, by incorporating these interfacial imperfections, the surface binding energy with intermediate species is improved [76]. One important approach to making TMOs better ORR electrocatalysts is to build structures that interact with one another at the interface. For example, to achieve bifunctional activity in alkaline HER/ORR, Liu et al. [75] created a 3D hybrid network that included hierarchically porous carbon nanofibers doped with boron, nitrogen, and iron carbide implanted in them. The network, depicted in Fig. 5a , was called FeMn@BNPCFs [75]. This catalyst exhibited excellent ORR activity with the E onset = 0.946 V and E 1/ 2 = 0.868 V (vs. RHE) (Fig. 5b). Both these values are more positive than those exhibited by the commercial 20 wt% Pt/C (E onset = 0.943 V vs. RHE, E 1/ 2 = 0.854 V vs. RHE), thereby confirming the superior ORR electrocatalytic capabilities of FeMn@BNPCFs. Additionally, FeMn@BNPCFs-900 exhibits a comparable Tafel slope (56.13 mV/dec) to that of commercial Pt/C (55.62 mV/dec) (Fig. 5c). Several variables contribute to the improved performance of FeMn@BNPCFs: (i) enhanced charge transport capacity, (ii) carbon defects abounding, (iii) active sites such as pyridine N-M species, B and N atoms doped within carbon nanofibers, and MnO nanocrystalline NPs; and (iv) 3D hierarchically macro-/mesoporous structures that work in tandem. In addition, owing to Fe's relatively low cost, vast abundance, and high sensitivity towards O2, Fe-oxides have been recognized as the most experimented TMOs-based ORR electrocatalysts. However, Fe-oxides exhibit low ORR activity which limits their utilization in electrochemical energy storage/conversion devices. Additionally, these oxides experience agglomeration and uncontrollable growth during their synthesis, which further degrades their performance. To overcome this issue, Wang et al. [63] embedded core-shell Fe3O4@N-doped-C (Fe3O4@NC) NPs into N-doped ordered interconnected hierarchical porous carbon (Fe3O4@NC/NHPC) (Fig. 6 (a-g), and Fig. 6j). The prepared Fe3O4@NC/NHPC exhibited exceptional ORR activity, with E onset = 0.898 V, E 1/ 2 = 0.803 V, and 4.77 mA/cm2. These values were comparable to that of commercial Pt/C, which exhibited an equal E 1/2 as well as limiting current density, with E onset = 0.934 V (Fig. 6h). The excellent ORR activity of Fe3O4@NC/NHPC was further confirmed by its Tafel slope of 54 mV/dec, which is lesser than that of Pt/C (65 mV/dec) (Fig. 6i). The characterization results indicated that N-Fe moieties, where N-atoms modified by metal species, acted as catalytic ORR active sites. Additionally, incorporation of Fe3O4 nanoparticles also leads to an increase in active sites which, in conjunction with N-doping, leads to the enhanced ORR activity exhibited by Fe3O4@NC/NHPC in this study. Table 1 shows the ORR Performance for various TMOs. 2.3 Transition metal sulfides According to their crystal structures, TMSs fall into one of two broad classes: layered MS2 and non-layered MxSy [81]. The layered structure of TM sulfides in groups 4–7 (M = Mo, W, Ta, etc.) is similar to that of graphite, but the non-layered structure is characteristic of groups 8–12 (M = Fe, Co, Ni) [81]. Changes in electrochemical characteristics among TMSs are a result of structural and chemical changes [82–84]. In layered MS2, S-atoms are sandwiched between two layers of TMs in a hexagonal arrangement. Using out-of-plane van der Waals forces, these layers are piled vertically on top of each other [81]. In contrast, when x = 1 and y = 2, the structures of non-layered MxSy tend to be pyrite or marcasite. In this pyrite structure, the transition metal atoms are bound octahedrally to neighboring S-atoms and are situated at face-centered cubic locations. The reason behind this is that the pyrite structure is a member of the Pa3 space group. The octahedral bonds between neighboring S-atoms and body-centered TM atoms characterize the marcasite structure's orthorhombic PNNM space group [81]. There are several approaches to designing TMSs as ORR electrocatalysts. These approaches aim to improve the electrocatalytic performance of materials by addressing their low electrical conductivity and limited active sites, which lead to slow electron transfer and reaction rates. Therefore, to increase catalytic activity, the design strategies mainly involve increasing the number of active sites, improving the electron transfer rate, and optimizing the adsorption and desorption energy of intermediates by adjusting the electronic structure (such as the d-band position, work function, and valence orbital level) [76]. Recently, carbon nanoparticles have been suggested as conductive substrates to be integrated into TMSs as part of a design strategy. The ORR electrocatalytic process encounters significant electron transfer resistance because TMSs are semiconducting. Nanomaterials made of carbon have a large surface area and strong electrical conductivity, making them potentially suitable conductive substrates for hosting tunneling magnetic sensors. The design of electrocatalysts also makes use of phase engineering. Physiochemical characteristics, including conductivity, surface activity, and electronic structure, tend to vary throughout phases. The type of electrocatalytic material used determines how phase engineering can be used to boost the catalytic activity of organic redox reactions. Designing TMS-based ORR electrocatalysts with morphology engineering in mind is essential. Experimental observation of the fact that the same phase with different morphologies exhibits distinct activities [76] demonstrates that the electroactivity of transition metal-based materials, including TMSs, is morphology-dependent. Because they help increase the number of catalytic active sites per unit mass, TMS compounds with smaller sizes, such as nanorods, nanowires, and nanoparticles, are typically very active for ORR catalysis. Additionally, a high mass transfer rate is enabled by TMS nanostructures with a large surface area, which exposes more active sites. It has been found that out of all the TMSs, cobalt sulfides have the greatest activity for oxygen reactions. This is particularly true for Co9S8 since it is expected to have ORR kinetics comparable to Pt/C in acidic conditions [85]. For use in OER/ORR and rechargeable Zn-air battery solutions, Li et al. [85] synthesized a bifunctional catalyst (Co9S8/CNT) using an atomic layer deposition (ALD) approach (Fig. 7a ). A CNT scaffold structure with a large surface area was coated with a homogeneous, ultrathin layer of Co9S8 using an advanced ALD synthesis method (Fig. 7(b-c)). Because of its extremely thin structure, Co9S8 greatly enhances the exposed catalytic surface area. The ultrathin structure of Co9S8 made it easy to disseminate reactants to the active sites, which significantly improved the mass transfer process during electrocatalysis. The ALD cycle number allows for fine control of the layer thickness of Co9S8, leading to TMSs with a nanoscale, programmable morphology, a very desirable characteristic. The outcome was an ORR E onset of 0.94 V vs. RHE for the Co9S8/CNT and an E 1/2 of 0.82 V vs. RHE (Fig. 7d). The ORR activity of the Co9S8/CNT catalyst was superior to that of the uncoated CNTs, thin-film Co9S8, and ALD CoSx/CNT catalysts. The Tafel slope for the Co9S8/CNT catalyst was 59 mV/dec, which is significantly lower than the 70 mV/dec, as observed for the state-of-the-art Pt/C catalysts (Fig. 7e). This indicates that the Co9S8/CNT catalyst yields improved Tafel kinetics. With a high-power density of 200 mW/cm2 and an outstanding cycling stability of 96 h, a zinc-air battery based on Co9S8 may be described. Electrocatalysts based on Co9S8 have a tough time with long-term cycling because of their poor durability and weak catalytic activity. Their tiny surface area, strong aggregation, and innately low electric conductivity cause this. The Co9S8 NPs doped with carbon dots (CDs) were grown in a C-matrix that was co-doped with -N and -S (Fig. 8a ) by Zhang et al. [86]. Because CDs bind so well to Co9S8 and may coordinate with Co2+ ions via their numerous surface functional groups, this tactic successfully inhibited the development and aggregation of Co9S8 (Fig. 8(b-d)). An additional benefit was the large specific surface area achieved by cross-linking CDs between PANI fibers. Also, the composite electrocatalyst system is more stable and has better conductivity because the Co9S8-carbon interfaces are better. All things considered, the half-wave potential of 0.84 V vs. RHE (Fig. 8(e-F)) indicates that the ORR performance of Co9S8/CD@NSC is excellent. The remarkable performance of the Co9S8/CD@NSC electrocatalyst for ORR applications was demonstrated by its half-wave value, which was comparable to that of the commercial benchmark Pt/C electrocatalyst (0.87 V vs. RHE). In comparison to the other samples in the investigation, Co9S8/CD@NSC has the best ORR catalytic activity (76.2 mV/dec) and shows similar kinetics to the Pt/C catalyst (Fig. 8 g), thanks to its significantly lower Tafel slope (125 mV/dec) compared to Pt/C. When comparing the two materials' long-term stability, Co9S8/CD@NSC performed better than Pt/C. After 40,000 s, the former retained 89.5 % of its initial current, while the latter retained just 79.1 % (Fig. 8h). The findings provide credence to the idea that Co9S8/CD@NSC could be a game-changing organic reduction reaction catalyst in the future. Metallic cobalt pyrite (CoS2) is a material that has shown high intrinsic conductivity for rapid charge transfer and as such has garnered significant research attention as an ORR pre-catalyst. However, its practical applications are greatly hindered owing to its susceptibility to oxidation, severe decomposition in alkaline electrolytes, and moderate ORR activity. The number of exposed active sites and the intrinsic activity of each site are the two key factors that influence electrocatalytic activity. Thus, NCoS2 YSS was created by Lu et al. [87] by combining a porous yolk-shell structure with nitrogen doping via a simple hydrothermal and low-temperature vulcanization method. For oxygen adsorption and desorption, the porous yolk-shell nanostructure is an ideal shape because of its large electrolyte-electrode contact area, high specific area, and limited ion-diffusion path. Furthermore, it is known that nitrogen doping can improve the electrical characteristics and, thus, the activity of each site. Instead of using the typically used NH3 gas, which is known to be highly corrosive, the researchers used ammonium hydroxide as the etchant and nitrogen source to keep the electrocatalyst's yolk-shell structure intact. The result is that NCoS2 YSS has an onset potential of 0.95 V and a half-wave potential of 0.81 V. They also achieve a diffusion-limiting current density of 5.6 mA/cm2. These findings are in comparison to commercial 20 wt.% Pt/C, which also displays a 1.0 V onset potential, 0.85 V half-wave potential, and 5.6 mA/cm2 diffusion-limiting current density. This proves that NCoS2 YSS has outstanding ORR capabilities. With a Tafel slope value of 52 mV/dec, NCoS2 YSS exhibits fast ORR kinetics, according to Tafel analysis. The NCoS2 YSS electrocatalyst has proven to be highly effective in terms of ORR kinetics, as this value is lower than Pt/C's (55 mV/dec). A Zn-air battery that used NCoS2 YSS as its air cathode showed superior cycle stability (56 % after 165 h) when compared to a Zn-air battery driven by Pt/C||RuO2, which showed cycling stability of 47 % after only 24 h. Guo et al. [88] carried out another study involving CoS2 in which (N, P)-doped CoS2 nanoclusters were embedded inside TiO2 nanoporous films (denoted as N,P/CoS2@TiO2). Phosphorus doping is beneficial in the synthesis of CoS2 electrocatalysts as phosphorus atoms inhibit corrosion of the electrocatalyst by “holding frame on the surface of CoS2, thereby creating ample space to bridge the electrolyte with CoS2”. Incorporating nanoporous film catalysts possessing 3D open frameworks is an effective method for inhibiting the aggregation of electrocatalysts and decomposition challenges normally encountered during the utilization of other nanostructures such as nanoflowers and nanosheets. N, P/CoS2@TiO2 exhibits an onset potential of 0.91 V, which is close to that exhibited by Pt/C (0.93 V). It can thus be confirmed that significant ion exchange between N and CoS2 has taken place, along with the provision of ample active sites and surface defects by the N-dopant. The half-wave potential exhibited by N, P/CoS2@TiO2 is similarly impressive (0.71 V) and thus indicates the superior ORR kinetics of the electrocatalyst. In a study by Yang et al. [89], well-defined trimetallic CoNiFe sulfide mesoporous nanospheres (denoted as CoNiFe-S MNs) were synthesized from metal-organic framework (MOF) precursors via a facile two-step solvothermal method (Fig. 9 (a-c)) for electrocatalytic applications in Zn-air batteries. Mesoporous materials have garnered significant attention as promising electrocatalysts owing to their high porosity and large surface area for the exposure of catalytic active sites. Additionally, the choice to utilize MOF precursors is a deliberate one owing to their controllable composition and highly enriched porous structures, both of which are desirable properties for electrocatalytic materials. As a result of these factors, the CoNiFe-S MNs exhibit a half-wave potential of 0.78 V which is comparable to that of commercial Pt/C (0.842 V) (Fig. 9(d-e)). Furthermore, the four-electron transfer process is confirmed to be the dominant ORR mechanism by the electron transfer number of CoNiFe-S derived from the Koutecky-Levich plot, exhibiting values between 3.86–3.97 at different potentials for 0.2–0.3 V vs. RHE (Fig. 9f). Table 2 showed the ORR Performance for various TMSs. 2.4 Transition metal phosphides Transition metal phosphides are solid-state compounds comprising phosphorus with metallic or semi-metallic elements [90]. The crystal structures of TMPs range from very simple ionic structures like NaCl-type LaP to more sophisticated ones like skutterudite-type LaRu4P12 and ThCr2Si2-type LaRu2P2 [90]. The physicochemical and electrochemical properties of TMPs can be further categorized based on their composition and the components that make them up. Typically, TMPs that are metal-rich (x > y in MxPy) or stoichiometric (x = y = 1 in MxPy) show semiconducting properties. However, in rare instances, when there is a lot of metal-metal bonding, they can show metallic or even superconductive qualities. Stoichiometric metal phosphides, which include a lot of metal, are very resistant to oxidation and chemicals, and they're very hard as well [90,91]. The presence of relatively strong M-P bonds in these compounds is the reason for these properties. Another great thing about many transition metal phosphides is that they can withstand weak acids and bases, making them ideal for use in electrocatalysis. Transition metal phosphides (y > x in MxPy) that are rich in phosphorus (y > x) show a lot of P-P bonding because phosphorus can form a lot of different oligomers and clusters with itself [90]. Consequently, compared to metal-rich and stoichiometric metal phosphides, TMPs that are rich in phosphorus have lower thermal stabilities, lower hardness, and higher reactivities. One of the strategies employed to enhance the intrinsic activity of TMP electrocatalysts is elemental doping. In recent years, this elemental doping has involved cation doping, anion doping, and anion and cation dual doping. In general, incorporating dopant elements can lead to the modulation of the TMP catalyst's electronic structure. This gives rise to remarkable changes in the physiochemical properties of TMPs [41]. The ideal quantity of dopant elements can usually be calculated theoretically in advance, allowing for fine-grained control of atomic-scale catalytic activity. To further improve TMP catalytic activity, interfacial engineering is also used. Electrocatalysts with improved electrocatalytic activity can be realized through the logical design of multicomponent heterogeneous structures. The physiochemical characteristics at the interface are often very different from those of the bulk phase because of the direct physical contact between the phases [41]. Additionally, hybrid electrocatalysts generally display enhanced electron conductivity, rapid reaction kinetics, and optimized adsorption energies because of strong interfacial interactions. Theoretical calculations assist in revealing the interfacial interactions between each component, which include the interfacial synergistic effect and the electronic coupling effect. Finally, phase modification of TMPs is a crucial strategy that is realized via tuning metal/phosphorus stoichiometric ratios, single crystalline and amorphous structures. By focusing specifically on the regulation of the intrinsic properties of TMPs, phase modification can lead to enhanced electrocatalytic activities. Large-scale manufacturing of TMPs is hindered using hazardous phosphorus sources, including elemental phosphorus (PH3), trioctylphoshine (TOP), and red or yellow elemental phosphorus. Pyrolysis, a clean, easy-to-scale process that uses nontoxic metal and phosphorus precursors, was employed by Parra-Puerto et al. [92] to create carbon-supported MxPy (where M = Ni, Co, W, Cr, and Mo). Corrosion resistance, oxygen evolution rate (HER), and organic reduction reaction were among the electrocatalysts evaluated in electrolytes that were either acidic or alkaline. Among the catalysts that were evaluated, CO2P exhibited the highest ORR activity in both acidic and basic mediums. With an onset potential of 0.8 V vs. RHE at 0.5 mA/cm2, Co2P was within 80 mV of platinum's (Pt/C) onset potential. The dissolution of Co in the material and its subsequent precipitation as needles of single-crystal Co3O4 explain the rapid corrosion of Co2P, particularly in acidic environments. Nevertheless, the Co3O4 layer's development allowed for excellent activity and stability over 8 h at 1.6 V vs. RHE. The lowest Tafel slope of the electrocatalysts tested was 38 mV/dec, which was likewise displayed by Co2P. One reason why Co2P is so effective as an ORR catalyst is that, right at the start of the ORR, single-crystal needlelike cobalt oxide nanostructures are formed. These nanostructures have (111) facets that are highly dense with Co2+ sites, which are the active sites for the ORR. Caused by this, ORR showed almost no deterioration in the following 100 cycles. Yousef et al. designed a synthesis method for a transition metal phosphide-based electrocatalyst that was both safe and scalable [93]. By pyrolyzing the gel that formed after hydrothermal treatment of a mixture of iron nitrate and phytic acid, the researchers were able to synthesize an electrocatalyst consisting of iron phosphide and carbon, abbreviated as FeP/C. In acidic environments, the FeP/C showed first-rate ORR kinetics, with a half-wave potential of 0.74 V vs. RHE and an onset potential of 0.86 V vs. RHE. The ORR mechanism was confirmed to follow the preferred 4-electron pathway by K-L plot which revealed that the average electron transfer number was 4.6. The excellent ORR activity observed for FeP/C is attributed to several factors. FeP/C has a sheet-like structure with many micro- and mesopores, giving it a large surface area (BET surface area = 1269 m2/g). This gives the electrolyte many ways to diffuse and increases the contact area between the electrolyte and active materials. Another benefit is that it makes it easier for electrons to gather on the surface of the electrode. With enough P-C interactions present, carbon's electroneutrality was compromised. Furthermore, ORR activity is enhanced owing to the presence of Fe which assisted in the breaking of O=O bonds. Norouzi et al. [94] created a porous P and Fe-doped carbon electrocatalyst (PFeC) using a simple and inexpensive synthesis approach including triphenylphosphine and iron (II) chloride (Fig. 10a ). With an onset potential of 1.01 V against RHE, a half-wave potential of 0.88 V vs. RHE, and a limiting current of −8.38 mV/cm2 (Fig. 10b), PFeC-900 outperformed the other electrocatalysts that were tested for ORR production. Validating PFeC-900′s outstanding performance, these values were competitive with commercial Pt/C (Eonset = 1.04 V vs. RHE, E 1/ 2 = 0.90 V vs. RHE, jlim = −8.70 mV/cm2). Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 10e, PFeC-900 exhibited an ORR mechanism similar to Pt/C, as its Tafel slope was 58 mV/dec, which was also equivalent to Pt/C's 53 mVdec−1. Both the catalyst's physicochemical characteristics and its surface shape contribute to PFeC-900′s outstanding performance. The test sample with the highest concentration of iron and phosphorus atoms, PFeC-900, has a large number of active sites for ORR. The fast ORR kinetics are caused by the combined effects of the large overall pore volume (0.76 cm3/g) and the substantial mesoporous volume (0.53 cm3/g). In addition, the electrocatalyst surface becomes doped with Fe2P particles during synthesis (Fig. 10(c-d)). These particles serve as active centers and are supported on P-doped porous carbon, which increases the ORR activity even more because of the combined effects of the Fe-P species and the mesopore content. Through thermal treatment of electro-spun ZIF-67 spheres, Liu et al. [95] reported to have prepared a CoP-decorated N,P-doped necklace-like carbon electrocatalyst (CoP@N,P-CNFs) (Fig. 11 (a-b)). Fig. 11c shows that the resulting CoP@N,P-CNFs had onset and half-wave potential values of 0.96 and 0.87 V vs. RHE, respectively, which are almost identical to the values shown by commercial Pt/C. The computed electron transfer number for CoP@N, P-CNFs was around 3.89, indicating that the 4-electron channel is the primary one for the ORR (Fig. 11d). The improvement of the electrocatalytic reaction kinetics is greatly aided by the synergistic effect that is created by the dual doping of P and N. This is because the electrical conductivity of the carbon backbone is substantially improved when P or N is used as a dopant. In addition, the necklace-like shape of the CoP@N,P-CNFs (Fig. 11b) allows for effective mass transfer, which helps the reactants reach the active sites during catalysis. Table 3 shows the ORR Performance for various TMPs. 2.5 Single atom catalysts Isolated atoms supported on a carrier are called single-atom catalysts [46]. The integral active sites of SACs are the separated metal atom centers that have been changed by the associated support. Metal particles reduced to the size of individual atoms improve catalytic performance in three main ways: (i) the size effect, which causes electron confinement to produce distinct HOMO-LUMO orbitals and discrete energy level distributions; (ii) the low-coordination environment of the metal center atoms that are actively catalyzing the reaction; and (iii) strong interactions between the metal and the support, which allows for improved charge transfer between the active sites and the support [46]. Further, when particles are reduced to the size of a single or double atom, additional characteristics emerge [99,100]. When looking at SACs through the lens of physical structure, it becomes clear that the atomic centers of the active sites are what give them their unique properties. This means that SACs have the best qualities of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. They have stable structures and compositions, are easy to separate from the reaction system, and have active sites that are all the same size and have low coordination environments [46]. In addition, SACs have a metal dispersion that is almost equal to 1, which indicates that all the atoms in a specific SAC can be involved in catalysis. This increases the utilization of the atoms and, in turn, the catalytic capacity of the matrix [101]. The most cost-effective catalyst is SACs because of this very reason. The coordination environment determines the inherent selectivity and catalytic activity of SACs. To be more precise, this includes the types of metal atomic centers, the surroundings around those centers, and the geometric layout of the supports [2]. Three distinct approaches to influencing SACs' coordinating environmental centers emerge from these three classes. Controlling the locations of atomic centers in metals is the first. Choosing the right metal atoms is a direct way to adjust the inherent catalytic performance of SACs since the centers of metal atoms are thought of as the active sites for ORR. The poorer the binding of oxygenated intermediates to a metal atom, its d-band center will be lower. Researchers aim to do this by studying the adsorption energy of intermediates that have been oxygenated [2]. Altering the space around atomic metal centers is the focus of the second approach to coordination environments. Since adjusting the nitrogen atoms' coordination numbers is a potential method for improving ORR performance, this approach is mostly used for M-N-C SACs. The ORR activity of SACs can also be influenced by the coordination of various nitrogen atom types with active metal centers. The S, P, O, and other elemental heteroatoms can form comparable coordination. Changing the geometry of the carbon support is the third tactic for influencing the coordinating environment. An important factor influencing the electrical structure of SACs is the geometric configuration of the carbon support. The impact of the carbon support, which significantly alters the SAC's subsequent activities, makes it possible to tune the SACs for optimal ORR performance [102]. For ORR, the SACs typically utilized are M-N-C SACs, which have active metal centers (M = Mn, Fe, Co, etc.) that are coordinated to nitrogen on a conductive support, which is mainly carbon or carbon-based [44]. In general, these SACs are prepared by pyrolysis of templates with predefined metal-nitrogen coordination. Such templates include hydrogels, metal complexes, and MOFs. As a result of the atomic centers in SACs being the active sites, a method of improving the overall M-N-C SAC ORR activity would be to increase doping at the metal sites. Other methods that have been put forth to improve the catalytic activity and stability of M-N-C SACs include (i) determining the promoting ORR mechanism of metals such as Fe, Co, Ni or Mn, (ii) determining the role of carbon in the electrocatalysts, (iii) designing structure-defined 3D MOF precursors with M-N4 coordination, and (iv) determining the mechanisms by which the electrocatalysts degrade [49–51,103]. As an efficient ORR electrocatalyst, Fe-based M-N-C SACs demonstrate promise as FeN4 motifs, which are just as active for the ORR as Pt, can be accommodated in graphene co-doped with N and Fe, according to density-functional theory predictions [44]. The distinctive microstructures of ZIF-8 allow for high-density FeN4 site creation, which in turn makes it an attractive sacrificial precursor for the synthesis of Fe-based M-N-C SACs. Most of these SACs are made by pyrolyzing composite precursors at high temperatures. For ORR electrocatalysis, Ao et al. [104] developed a N-doped porous carbon (FeAC@FeSA-N-C) that anchored Fe atomic clusters and atomically distributed Fe-N4 sites (Fig. 12 (a-d)). The half-wave potential of the produced catalyst was 0.912 V vs. RHE, surpassing that of both commercial Pt/C (0.897 V) and single-atom Fe-N-C (FeSA-N-C, 0.844 V vs. RHE) (Fig. 12e). A spatial isolation technique based on the TAPB-PDA covalent organic framework (COF) template was employed to accomplish the coexistence of Fe single atoms and Fe nanoclusters. COFs allow the easy passage of Fe ions into their cavities and provide N sites that can bind the anchoring Fe cations when used as a template to synthesize Fe-N-C catalysts. As anticipated for M-N-C SACs, DFT simulations showed that the Fe-N4 site is the primary active site for ORR (Fig. 12(F-i)). However, the impact of Fe nanocluster integration on the existing single-atom Fe active sites was of special interest. By enhancing ORR activity by lowering the binding strength of *OH, the interaction between the Fe atom in the Fe-N4 site and the Fe nanoclusters causes a shift of the d-band center to a lower energy level. Thus, the intrinsic activity of the single-atom Fe active sites is further enhanced by the Fe nanoclusters. The free radical species generated during the Fenton reaction, which is catalyzed by Fe, cause a considerable decrease in activity and a major problem with the durability of Fe-based M-N-C SACs [44]. Co-based M-N-C SACs, an alternative electrocatalyst with improved stability, have so far attracted interest. Similarly, to M-N-C SACs based on Fe, those based on Co are mostly made from precursors of sacrificial ZIF. In a work by Wu et al. [105], a catalyst for the 4e-ORR with a single Co atom contained within N-doped hollow carbon spheres (Co-N4/C) was created (Fig. 13a and Fig. 13d). The catalyst had an onset potential of 0.68 V in neutral conditions. The intrinsic electrocatalytic activity of ORR catalysts is significantly reduced when hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is reduced; therefore, this was done to alleviate that problem. An electrochemical kinetic study demonstrated that the Co-N4 catalytic sites mostly enhance the direct 4e-reaction pathway, as opposed to the 2e-reaction pathway, which includes H2O2 as an intermediary (Fig. 13b and c). Fig. 13e and f show that DFT calculations further validated that the decrease of H2O2 was limited by the poor adsorption of H2O2 on the porphyrin-like Co centers. This made it possible to sense O2 very specifically, better than the commercial Pt/C catalyst in monitoring brain oxygen in living organisms, and it gave the Co-N4/C electrocatalyst better resistance to H2O2 current interference. Similar to Fe-based M-N-C SACs, Co-based M-N-C SACs show low endurance under high-potential reaction conditions [44]. Because of this, their use in devices like PEMFCs is severely restricted. Researchers have taken a keener interest in Mn-based M-N-C SACs because of their improved stability and similar activity to that of Fe- and Co-based M-N-C SACs. The expected ORR activity and stability are demonstrated by Mn-based M-N-C SACs, including carbon and MnN4 moieties, according to preliminary DFT calculations. Bai et al. [106] made a graphene material called Mn@NG by heating it up to high temperatures and then acid-leaching it. This was done so that it could be used as an oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) electrocatalyst. The ORR activity of the Mn@NG catalyst was outstanding, with a half-wave potential of 0.82 V vs. RHE and an onset potential of 0.95 V vs. RHE. Using HAADF-STEM, EXFAS, and theoretical models, the manganese mononuclear sites were validated. In comparison to graphitic-N, pyridinic-N, MnN3O-G, the Mn3O4 (001) surface, and MnN3-G, the theoretical overpotential on the MnN4-G site was determined to be the lowest at 0.63 V, indicating that it is the primary active site for ORR. The identification of the specific active sites of M-N-C single-atom catalysts (SACs) is still not well understood. Wu et al. created Cu-N-C single-atom catalysts (SACs) using a two-step method (Fig. 14a ) to study and determine the active sites responsible for the oxygen reduction reaction [107]. The Cu-N-C SACs with a copper content of 2.0 wt.% demonstrated the most significant activity for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), as evidenced by a half-wave potential of 0.83 V and a limiting current density of 5.25 mA/cm2 (Fig. 14b). This activity is equivalent to that of commercial Pt/C under the same conditions (0.837 V and 5.25 mA/cm2, respectively). Furthermore, the Tafel slope of 2.0 wt.% Cu-N-C SAC was much lower at 37 mV/dec compared to Pt/C, which had a Tafel slope of 66 mV/dec. This result provides further evidence of the improved reaction kinetics of Cu-N-C SAC, as shown in Fig. 14c. The ex-situ characterizations indicate that the Cu-N-C SACs have a consistent and clearly defined structure consisting of Cu2+-N4 atoms that are scattered at the atomic level. This structure appears to remain unaltered both before and after the ORR. Operando X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES), in conjunction with DFT calculations, demonstrated that the Cu2+-N4 structure transformed the low-coordinated Cu+-N3 structure and subsequently to the Cu+-N2 structure. Furthermore, it was established that the dynamic changes in structure are mostly influenced by the applied potential, as seen in Fig. 14d and 14e. The active site for ORR was found to be the Cu2+-N3 structure after it underwent evolution. This conclusion was based on two main factors: (i) the increase in the ratio of Cu+/Cu2+ as the potential was applied, and (ii) the lower free energy associated with each step compared to the Cu2+-N4 structure. Table 4 shows the ORR Performance for various SACs. 2.6 Dual-Atomic catalysts SACs have received considerable focus in the field of O2 catalysis due to their ability to utilize active atoms with 100 % efficiency and their ability to modify the microenvironment of metal centers. Nevertheless, the fact that SACs have just one active site leads to a fixed adsorption mode. In addition, the intermediate products formed during multistep reactions, such as ORR, that bind to a single metal site exhibit adsorption energies that are correlated with each other [48]. This results in the occurrence of the scaling relationship limit, where it becomes extremely challenging to effectively regulate the adsorption of each intermediate on the individual site at the same time for a specific multistep process [48]. As a result, dual-atom catalysts have been receiving increasing study focus due to their superior catalytic activity in comparison to SACs. DACs exhibit inherent synergistic effects in which two metal centers catalyze distinct core stages independently, resulting in enhanced overall catalytic performance. The synergistic effect is one of the three primary sources of activity in DACs. The remaining sources of activity are (i) the adsorption effect, where the scaling relationship limit is surpassed due to changes in adsorption structures caused by the availability of extra sites; and (ii) the electronic effect, where one metal center functions as the active site while the other acts as an electronic regulator [48]. Digital-to-analogue converters (DACs) can be classified into two primary categories: (i) homonuclear DACs, which include the same type of atoms, and (ii) heteronuclear DACs, which involve different types of atoms. Homonuclear DACs have a catalytic center that consists of two identical metallic atoms [112]. In addition, homonuclear DACs have symmetrical spots for reactant molecules to attach and are often more thermodynamically stable than SACs. Heteronuclear DACs, in contrast, have a heterodimeric active site in which the dual atom consists of distinct metallic atoms. Heteronuclear DACs have adsorption sites that are not the same, which makes it easy to change the electrical structure of the d-band. Consequently, by achieving appropriate interaction with the intermediates, the catalytic performance is enhanced. The creation of DACs and the regulation of the microenvironment around individual metal sites have both made great strides, but the challenge of incorporating two metal atoms in the correct configuration still exists [113]. Important methods for preparing DACs are as follows: (i) Pyrolysis coupling approach: This method involves mixing two metal atoms, placing them on supports, and pyrolyzing them at high temperatures to create metal-metal pairs through the coupling effect. For instance, Lu et al. [114], synthesized a Zn-Co DAC using N-doped carbon as a substrate, with ZnCl2 and Co(Ac)2 as the metal sources (Fig. 15a ). The evidence of atomically dispersed Fe/Co species was confirmed by the HAADF-STEM picture and XAFS analysis (Fig. 15(b-d)). Similarly, Zhang et al. [115], created a Fe-Co DAC by combining Fe2+ and Co2+ salts with formamide and then subjecting it to solvothermal treatment and annealing at 900 °C (Fig. 15e). The characterization analysis verified the presence of Fe(N3)-Co(N3) DAC, as shown in Fig. 15(F–j). (ii) Pyrolysis-free strategy to prepare DACs: The method described above is good enough to make DAC, but it creates metallic nanoparticles and doesn't load many active sites onto the carbon support. Furthermore, in the pyrolysis method, samples are heated to high temperatures, creating a challenge to finding the actual active sites. On the other hand, with the pyrolysis-free approach to preparing DACs, the catalytic activity of specific active sites can be precisely controlled by using activity descriptors. However, there is still a major technological hurdle to the direct synthesis of pyrolysis-free DACs using uniformly distributed dual-atomic sites on conducting substrates [116]. For instance, using pyrolysis-free approach, Sanad et al. [117] created a dual-atomic site (Co and Cu) containing MOF-based material with Co-O-Cu linkage using a low-temperature hydrothermal method, and the results suggested that the transfer of electrons between two metal sites (Cu2+ and Co2+) occurred via O-bridging. In a similar way, Ma et al. [118], employed the solvothermal strategy to create Fe and Co-based DAC, using FePc and CoPc. The results suggested that both the FePc and CoPc were stacked against each other, creating a heterostructure containing dual-atomic sites. Further, the experimental and theoretical findings suggested that the interface of FePc and CoPc acted as charge transfer carriers to facilitate the catalytic process. So, the pyrolysis-free way of making DACs is very helpful for learning about their structural-reactivity properties and the catalytic active sites. DACs possessing a minimal number of active sites on the bridge have been recognized as the optimal materials for electrocatalysis in upcoming times. This is because MOCs have a wider range of uses compared to SACs, thanks to their larger concentration of metal atoms and the presence of more flexible top and bridge active sites. Augmenting the metal atom loading of SACs results in a subsequent augmentation in the number of active sites, hence boosting the specific mass activity of the catalyst [34]. Nevertheless, SACs generally have a modest amount of metal content to preserve the dispersion of individual atoms. Furthermore, augmenting the metal loading of single-atom catalysts necessitates the use of specialized procedures, hence posing significant difficulties in their manufacture. DACs are utilized as a strategic approach to enhance the loading of atoms and, consequently, the effectiveness of the active sites. For homonuclear DACs, a higher supply of the metal precursor leads to an increase in atom loading [34]. DACs differ from SACs in their adsorption configuration of reactant molecules. Unlike SACs, DACs have multiple active sites that enable the bonding of one atom of the reactant molecule to two metal atoms. Alternatively, two atoms of the reactant molecule can bond to two metal atoms individually. By modifying the bonding of reactant molecules to the catalyst, it is possible to increase the likelihood of effective adsorption [34]. DACs can also be used as a tactic to augment the ORR pathway. DACs are used to boost the selectivity of the preferred 4e- ORR route. They also help to decrease the energy barrier for O2 dissociation and other ORR steps, resulting in improved ORR performance of the electrocatalyst. In a study conducted by He et al. [119] Fe and Co co-doped ZIF-8 s were used to produce atomically distributed Fe-Co dual metal sites, referred to as FeCo-NC. These sites were employed as bifunctional catalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER). A controlled pyrolysis method was used to make FeCo-NCs after chemically doping ZIF-8 s (Fig. 16a ). The FeCo-NC demonstrated exceptional oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) performance in alkaline conditions, with a half-wave potential of 0.877 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) and an onset potential of 1.05 V vs RHE (Fig. 16f). The FeCo-NC catalyst is more effective in catalyzing the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) compared to a commercial 40 % Pt/C catalyst. The Pt/C catalyst has a half-wave potential of 0.867 V versus RHE and an onset potential of 0.98 V vs RHE. Furthermore, the FeCo-NCs that were examined had the lowest Tafel slope of 69.06 mV/dec, as shown in Fig. 16 g. The improved ORR performance of this DAC can be attributed to multiple variables. The simultaneous presence of three types of active centers, specifically FeCo-N6, Fe-N4, and Co-N4, results in a synergistic effect that boosts the reversibility of oxygen processes. Furthermore, the DFT calculations demonstrate that the FeCo-N6 dual metal site exhibits considerably higher activity for ORR in comparison to the conventional single metal sites (Fig. 16(h-j)). The FeCo-NCs achieve efficient mass transfer because of their hierarchical mess-microporous structure (Fig. 16(b-e)). As a result, there is a high-power density and the battery maintains stable performance over a long period. Han et al. [120] created Co-Ni dual metal sites that were evenly distributed at the atomic level and incorporated into hollow carbon nanocubes that were doped with nitrogen. This was achieved by subjecting dopamine-coated metal-organic frameworks to pyrolysis. The resulting material was referred to as CoNi-SAs/NC. The CoNi-SAs/NC demonstrates exceptional performance in terms of ORR, with a notable half-wave potential of 0.76 V, a high onset potential of 0.88 V, and a substantial limiting current density of 4.95 mA/cm2. These results compare favorably to those of the commercially available Pt/C catalyst, which has respective values of 0.82 V, 0.90 V, and 5.09 mA/cm2. The outstanding ORR performance can be credited to the many single-atom active sites, together with the synergistic impact resulting from the diatomic structure within the porous conductive carbon frameworks. More precisely, the poor catalytic activity of undecorated N-doped carbon nanocubes demonstrates that the metal-N-C sites enhance the ORR process, in contrast to the NC sites. Furthermore, the electron transfer number was calculated to be 3.9 within the potential range of 0.3–0.8 V, which confirms a strong selectivity for ORR and an efficient four-electron mechanism. Chen et al. [121] successfully designed and made Fe-Mn electrocatalysts that are spread out in a nitrogen-containing carbon matrix. These are called Fe/Mn-Nx-C. These electrocatalysts were specifically engineered for use in Zn-air batteries, as shown in Fig. 17a . The electrocatalyst shows excellent ORR activity, with a half-wave potential of 0.88 V vs. RHE, an onset potential of 1.02 V vs RHE and a limiting current density of 5.7 mA/cm2 (Fig. 17d). The corresponding electron transfer number was determined to be c.a. 4.0 from K-L plot calculations hence confirming superior ORR selectivity as well as an efficient 4e−ORR mechanism (Fig. 17e). DFT calculations reveal a synergistic dual-site cascade reaction mechanism (Fig. 17c) in which the low adsorption energy of *OH on Fe-Nx site is overcome, followed by the transfer of *OH to the adjacent Mn-Nx sites (Fig. 17b). Therefore, the first three reaction steps during ORR occur on the Fe-Nx sites as opposed to the Mn sites, thereby generating *OOH and *O intermediates efficiently because of the lower energy barriers leading to enhanced ORR activity. Ye et al. [122] performed a study where they attached Fe2 clusters onto N-doped carbon material, referred to as Fe2 N-C, to be used as electrocatalysts for acidic ORR (Figs. 18a , 18(c–d)). The researchers presented a method to precisely adjust the quantity of Fe atom clusters attached to N-doped carbon, which improves the adjustability of the DAC and changes the way oxygen is adsorbed from a superoxo-like configuration to a peroxo-like configuration. Furthermore, the enhanced adjustability facilitated the customization of N species within the carbon matrix during pyrolytic synthesis, as well as the customization of oxygen adsorption in an end-on manner to promote activation. The Fe2 N-C demonstrated exceptional acidic ORR performance, with a half-wave potential of 0.78 V vs. RHE. This was 18 and 65 mV higher than the half-wave potentials displayed by Fe3 N-C and Fe1 N-C, respectively (Fig. 18b). Furthermore, Fe2 N-C demonstrated a Tafel slope of 83 mV/dec, which was lower than the Tafel slopes of Fe1 N-C and Fe3 N-C (169 and 108 mV/dec, respectively), as shown in Fig. 18e. The findings indicate a considerable correlation between the performance and kinetics of the acidic ORR) and the quantity of iron (Fe) atoms in clusters. Table 5 shows the ORR performance for various DACs. In conclusion, this section outlined the major developments in the development of ORR electrocatalysts, specifically TMOs, TMSs, TMPs, SACs, and DACs. Through a variety of synthesis strategies and procedures, remarkably active ORR electrocatalysts were developed, with a great majority competing favorably with the commercially available Pt/C. In the following section, we provide prospective avenues for the development of ORR electrocatalysts, targeting avenues that we believe will aid in the mitigation of challenges faced in ORR electrocatalyst development currently. 3 Prospects Problems with stability, complex synthesis methods, thorough electrochemical interface characterization, and nano- or hybrid-structural engineering are among the most significant obstacles to the creation of affordable electrocatalysts [127]. An important obstacle in fuel cell and metal-air battery applications for ORR is the slow kinetics of oxygen electrocatalysis. Improving our knowledge of oxygen electrocatalysis and its differences from catalyst chemistry is essential for constructing high-performance ORR electrocatalysis. This can be achieved by doing additional experiments. This review summarizes the findings of numerous investigations into the impact of surface area, doping, crystal structure, composition, and defect type on ORR catalyst performance. This is a promising development, but their high design costs and complexity prevent them from being used commercially. Because of this, most of these electrocatalysts can only be used in small-scale laboratory experiments [58]. Catalysts with outstanding ORR performance, together with other desirable properties such as low material development costs, stable crystal structure, and ease of processing, are required for commercial production. When designing fuel cells, it is crucial to take the catalyst loading (mass per unit area) into account. The consequences of loading catalysts, however, have not been thoroughly studied in fuel cell research [58]. Particularly for metal-air batteries, a lightweight cathode is required. Hence, to develop lightweight catalysts with a high surface area and more exposed active sites, future research on ORR electrocatalysts should center on studying catalyst efficiency at different weight loadings. One of the major challenges to be addressed in the development of ORR electrocatalysts is their low catalytic activity, especially in the case of TMOs, TMPs, TMSs, and SACs [128]. There are a few ways in which intrinsic catalytic activity can be improved; (i) heteroatom-doping and vacancy engineering, in which heteroatom dopants and defect control can modify the local electronic structure, especially in those electrocatalysts utilizing a carbon substrate thereby effectively improving the catalytic activity; (ii) morphology engineering, in which engineering 3D architectures such as core-shell structures leads to the enhancement of mass transfer efficiency through the creation of more 3D electron transfer channels as well as exposing ample and easily access metal active sites; and (iii) hybridization engineering strategies, in which metal/metal compounds are coupled with conductive carbon nanomaterials such as graphene and N-doped carbon nanotubes [128]. This strategy improves electrical conductivity, and due to the synergistic effects arising between the components, hybrid electrocatalysts exhibit enhanced catalytic activity. ORR electrocatalysts undergo significant corrosion because of the high oxidation potential that these catalysts are subjected to during the charging process [128] thus affecting their stability. The stability of SACs, for example, falls within the range of 10–100 h [44]. This is much lower than the DOE goal of 8000 h and as such a large gap exists between preliminary laboratory tests and industrial applications. It is imperative, therefore, to ensure that the durability of the electrocatalysts is high enough to withstand the oxidation potentials and thus enhance the catalyst's lifetime and stability. A possible strategy to incorporate to mitigate this challenge is the direct growth of catalysts on highly corrosion-resistant conductive substrates such as carbon cloth or nickel foam (Fig. 19 ). To create stable and effective ORR electrocatalysts, it is essential to learn more about active sites [128]. The mechanism of ORR has not been well studied due to a lack of sufficient theoretical prediction and characterization methods. Therefore, particularly for TMPs and TMSs, the evaluation of the actual active site and ORR mechanism, as well as the type of active sites, remain unclear. Consequently, it is critical to provide cutting-edge in-situ characterization methods that can help gather data on the intricate ORR reaction mechanism in real-time. Advancements in DAC characterization methods are necessary because existing methods (such as AC STEM and XAS) have limitations that hinder precise binuclear structure characterization [39]. We can find more efficient electrocatalysts faster if we combine machine learning with DFT calculations. Specifically, the machine-learning-accelerated, high-throughput DFT framework can be used to study the activity's origin and find out how to make DACs for various processes [35,129]. Most DACs are supported by carbon-based materials; hence, there is a dearth of research on DACs tied to other types of support materials. Due to the synergistic interaction of metal atoms, the catalytic effects of various support materials, such as metals or metal oxides, may vary [34]. To that end, research into DACs supported by materials other than carbon is required. 4 Conclusions The development of suitable ORR electrocatalysts is crucial to the development of energy storage technology such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Furthermore, it is imperative to develop electrocatalysts that are not only exceptional in terms of electrocatalytic performance but are also cost-effective as we begin to move away from expensive rare metal catalysts such as Pt being utilized at large currently. In this review, we have provided an overview of recent advances in the development of electrocatalytic non-Pt-based ORR materials. We have analyzed the chemistry of TMOs, TMSs, TMPs, SACs, and DACs, specifically regarding their utilization as ORR electrocatalysts, to showcase the underlying mechanisms behind the enhanced ORR activity exhibited by these materials. Doping of these materials, particularly N-doping, is revealed to be the most dominant design pathway across these materials and has received significant attention in this review. Other design pathways, such as composition, defect engineering, and morphology engineering, are also discussed. Further, we have provided directions in which future research can align itself and pursue to mitigate the challenges faced in the development of ORR electrocatalysts currently. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is essential in fuel cells and metal-air batteries for converting and storing energy. Nevertheless, these devices suffer from ORR's slow kinetics at cathode surfaces, necessitating effective electrocatalysts. To meet the practical application of these devices, various ORR electrocatalysts, including transition metal oxides (TMOs), sulfides (TMSs), phosphides (TMPs), and single-atom catalysts (SACs), have been developed, each with its issues related to limited activity, selectivity, and durability. Although TMOs possessed promise towards ORR, their limited conductivity and poor selectivity motivated the researcher to perform their sulfurization and phosphorization, resulting in TMSs, TMPs, and SACs, which displayed good ORR. However, at a practical level, these catalysts still exhibited poor selectivity and durability, introducing a novel class of electrocatalysts, ‘dual-atom catalysts (DACs)’. DACs have many advantages, including maximum atomic utilization in catalysis and a well-established activity descriptor, over other electrocatalysts. However, an assessment of DAC's evolution, their promise towards ORR, and the learned concepts to design efficient ORR catalysts is required. The purpose of this review is to provide a road map of the transition of electrocatalysts from TMOs to DACs with recent advancements in chemistry, structural-functional relationships, advantages, and disadvantages. In addition, the challenges, and relative prospects of various critical parameters of ORR electrocatalysts are also covered systematically.
coredata.dc:title: Progress, challenges, and prospects with electrocatalyst (From transition metal oxides to dual-atom catalysts) for oxygen reduction reaction
